title: 3 John Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 3 John chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 3 John Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 3 John Chapter 1.

questions.question: To whom is the elder writing in 3 John 1:1?
options: Gaius
Diotrephes
Demetrius
John
questions.correctAnswer: Gaius
questions.explanation: The elder writes to the wellbeloved Gaius, as stated in 3 John 1:1.

questions.question: What does the elder wish for Gaius in 3 John 1:2?
options: To prosper and be in health
To receive gifts
To travel safely
To write more letters
questions.correctAnswer: To prosper and be in health
questions.explanation: The elder wishes above all things that Gaius may prosper and be in health, even as his soul prospers, according to 3 John 1:2.

questions.question: Why did the elder rejoice greatly according to 3 John 1:3?
options: Because the brethren testified of the truth in Gaius
Because he received a gift
Because he was going to see Gaius soon
Because the church grew in numbers
questions.correctAnswer: Because the brethren testified of the truth in Gaius
questions.explanation: The elder rejoiced greatly when the brethren came and testified of the truth that is in Gaius as he walks in the truth, stated in 3 John 1:3.

questions.question: What is the elder's greatest joy as mentioned in 3 John 1:4?
options: To hear that his children walk in truth
To receive letters from friends
To visit many churches
To give gifts to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: To hear that his children walk in truth
questions.explanation: The elder states he has no greater joy than to hear that his children walk in truth, according to 3 John 1:4.

questions.question: According to 3 John 1:5, how does Gaius do towards the brethren and strangers?
options: Faithfully whatsoever he does
Only sometimes
With hesitation
Not at all
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfully whatsoever he does
questions.explanation: The elder commends Gaius for doing faithfully whatsoever he does towards the brethren and strangers in 3 John 1:5.

questions.question: What have the strangers borne witness of before the church according to 3 John 1:6?
options: Gaius' charity
The elder's wisdom
The church's wealth
The strangers' own works
questions.correctAnswer: Gaius' charity
questions.explanation: The strangers have borne witness of Gaius' charity before the church as mentioned in 3 John 1:6.

questions.question: Why did the strangers take nothing from the Gentiles as per 3 John 1:7?
options: For his name's sake
Because they were poor
To avoid conflict
Because they were instructed not to
questions.correctAnswer: For his name's sake
questions.explanation: They took nothing of the Gentiles for his name's sake, according to 3 John 1:7.

questions.question: Who is described as loving to have the preeminence and not receiving the elder in 3 John 1:9?
options: Diotrephes
Demetrius
Gaius
The elder
questions.correctAnswer: Diotrephes
questions.explanation: Diotrephes is described as loving to have the preeminence and not receiving the elder, per 3 John 1:9.

questions.question: What will the elder remember if he comes, according to 3 John 1:10?
options: The deeds of Diotrephes
The gifts of Gaius
The prayers of the brethren
The journeys of the strangers
questions.correctAnswer: The deeds of Diotrephes
questions.explanation: The elder says he will remember the deeds of Diotrephes, who prates against them with malicious words, as stated in 3 John 1:10.

questions.question: According to 3 John 1:11, who is of God?
options: He that doeth good
He that doeth evil
He that prates against others
He that loves preeminence
questions.correctAnswer: He that doeth good
questions.explanation: The verse states he that doeth good is of God, while he that doeth evil hath not seen God, in 3 John 1:11.

questions.question: What report does Demetrius have according to 3 John 1:12?
options: Good report of all men and of the truth itself
Bad report from the church
No report at all
A report about his travels
questions.correctAnswer: Good report of all men and of the truth itself
questions.explanation: Demetrius has a good report of all men and of the truth itself, as stated in 3 John 1:12.

questions.question: True or False: The elder planned to write many things with ink and pen to Gaius according to 3 John 1:13.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The elder says he had many things to write but would not write with ink and pen, according to 3 John 1:13.

questions.question: True or False: The elder trusts he will shortly see Gaius and speak face to face according to 3 John 1:14.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The elder expresses trust that he will shortly see Gaius and they will speak face to face, as in 3 John 1:14.

questions.question: True or False: According to 3 John 1:8, we ought to reject those who go forth for the name's sake.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse states we ought to receive such, that we might be fellowhelpers to the truth, not reject them (3 John 1:8).

questions.question: Complete the verse from 3 John 1:5: 'Beloved, thou doest ______ whatsoever thou doest to the brethren, and to strangers;'
options: faithfully
quickly
carelessly
doubtfully
questions.correctAnswer: faithfully
questions.explanation: The verse says 'thou doest faithfully whatsoever thou doest to the brethren, and to strangers;' as in 3 John 1:5.

medium.title: 3 John Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 3 John Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 3 John 1:2 teach us about the relationship between physical health and spiritual well-being?
options: Physical health is unrelated to the state of the soul
Prosperity in health should match the prosperity of the soul
Spiritual prosperity is less important than physical health
Only spiritual health matters; physical health is irrelevant
questions.correctAnswer: Prosperity in health should match the prosperity of the soul
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:2 expresses a wish for Gaius to prosper and be in health just as his soul prospers, indicating the importance of both physical and spiritual well-being.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because their acts of kindness go unnoticed. Based on 3 John 1:5-6, what biblical truth would you share about serving others?
options: Faithfulness in serving others is seen and testified before the church
Only serving church members is valuable
Kindness should be shown only to those who can repay it
Service to others is optional for believers
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness in serving others is seen and testified before the church
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 highlight that Gaius is commended for his faithful service to both brethren and strangers, which is witnessed before the church and honored.

questions.question: According to 3 John 1:7-8, what is the appropriate response to those who travel for the sake of the gospel?
options: Receive them and be fellowhelpers to the truth
Ignore them because they take nothing from the Gentiles
Judge them by how much money they bring
Only receive them if they belong to your local church
questions.correctAnswer: Receive them and be fellowhelpers to the truth
questions.explanation: The passage encourages receiving gospel workers who travel without taking support from outsiders, thereby partnering with them in the truth (3 John 1:7-8).

questions.question: What warning does 3 John 1:9-10 give about church leaders who seek preeminence?
options: They may reject apostolic authority and refuse hospitality to believers
They are praised for strong leadership
They always welcome those who come in the name of Christ
They avoid speaking malicious words
questions.correctAnswer: They may reject apostolic authority and refuse hospitality to believers
questions.explanation: Diotrephes is described as loving preeminence, not receiving the apostle or brethren, and even casting out those who want to receive them (verses 9-10).

questions.question: How does 3 John 1:11 instruct believers to choose between good and evil?
options: Believers should follow that which is good because it is of God
It is acceptable to do evil if it benefits you
Good and evil are indistinguishable to true Christians
Following evil demonstrates true knowledge of God
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should follow that which is good because it is of God
questions.explanation: The verse clearly instructs to not imitate evil but to imitate good, stating that those who do good are of God, and those who do evil have not seen God.

questions.question: Demetrius is mentioned positively in 3 John 1:12. What qualities does this passage highlight about him?
options: He has a good report from all and from the truth itself
He is accused of wrongdoing by the church
He seeks preeminence over others
He is unknown to the apostle
questions.correctAnswer: He has a good report from all and from the truth itself
questions.explanation: Demetrius is commended for having a good reputation both among people and regarding the truth, and the apostle confirms this testimony (verse 12).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride and a desire for preeminence. What example from 3 John 1 warns against this attitude?
options: Diotrephes, who loves to have the preeminence and acts maliciously
Demetrius, who has a good testimony
Gaius, who walks in the truth
The elder who writes lovingly
questions.correctAnswer: Diotrephes, who loves to have the preeminence and acts maliciously
questions.explanation: Diotrephes is identified as one who loves preeminence and behaves maliciously, refusing to welcome the brethren and slandering the apostle (3 John 1:9-10).

questions.question: How does 3 John 1:3-4 illustrate the joy a spiritual mentor experiences when their spiritual children live faithfully?
options: The elder rejoices greatly and has no greater joy than hearing they walk in truth
The elder is indifferent to their conduct
The elder is saddened by imperfections
The elder only cares about outward appearances
questions.correctAnswer: The elder rejoices greatly and has no greater joy than hearing they walk in truth
questions.explanation: These verses express the elder's great joy upon hearing that brethren walk in the truth, showing the delight in spiritual faithfulness.

questions.question: What practical principle about hospitality and support for traveling believers is taught in 3 John 1:6-8?
options: Believers should support traveling brethren who labor for the gospel without accepting outside help
Traveling preachers should finance their own journeys
Only family members deserve hospitality
Hospitality is optional and not emphasized
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should support traveling brethren who labor for the gospel without accepting outside help
questions.explanation: The passage commends supporting those who went forth for Christ’s name, taking nothing from the Gentiles, and encourages believers to receive them to be fellowhelpers to the truth.

questions.question: True or False: According to 3 John 1:13-14, the elder preferred to write many things to Gaius with ink and pen rather than meet face to face.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states the elder had many things to write but chose not to write with ink and pen, expressing a desire to see Gaius in person soon (verse 14).

questions.question: True or False: 3 John 1:11 teaches that those who do evil have truly seen God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that those who do evil have not seen God, contrasting them with those who do good who are of God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Beloved, I wish above all things that thou mayest prosper and be in health, even as thy _____ prospereth."
options: soul
body
faith
spirit
questions.correctAnswer: soul
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:2 expresses a wish for prosperity and health in the same measure as the soul prospers, highlighting spiritual well-being.

questions.question: Based on 3 John 1:1-2, how does the elder demonstrate the importance of truth in love?
options: He loves Gaius in the truth and prays for his well-being
He criticizes Gaius for lacking truth
He only cares about obedience, not love
He remains silent about Gaius's spiritual state
questions.correctAnswer: He loves Gaius in the truth and prays for his well-being
questions.explanation: The elder opens by expressing love for Gaius grounded in truth and prays for his prosperity and health (verses 1-2).

questions.question: What practical advice for church life is given in 3 John 1:10 regarding handling those who cause division?
options: Remember their deeds and be cautious of their malicious words
Ignore all conflicts and do nothing
Immediately excommunicate without warning
Encourage them to lead the church
questions.correctAnswer: Remember their deeds and be cautious of their malicious words
questions.explanation: Verse 10 warns of Diotrephes' malicious speech and refusal to receive brethren, implying the need for discernment in church relations.

questions.question: How does 3 John 1:4 encourage mentors and spiritual leaders in their role?
options: It affirms that hearing about spiritual growth of those they mentor brings great joy
It suggests leaders should not get emotionally involved
It advises leaders to focus only on church administration
It encourages leaders to demand perfection from followers
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms that hearing about spiritual growth of those they mentor brings great joy
questions.explanation: The elder states he has no greater joy than to hear his children walk in truth, encouraging leaders to rejoice in spiritual growth (verse 4).

hard.title: 3 John Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 3 John Chapter 1.

questions.question: In 3 John 1:1, the Elder addresses Gaius as 'wellbeloved.' What is the significance of the phrase 'whom I love in the truth' in the context of Johannine literature?
options: It emphasizes sincere love grounded in the reality of the Gospel
It refers to a secret knowledge known only to the Johannine community
It indicates a physical journey they shared together
It is a formal greeting used in all epistles
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes sincere love grounded in the reality of the Gospel
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:1 highlights the Elder's love for Gaius 'in the truth,' reflecting the Johannine theme that genuine love is inseparable from living in the truth of Christ's message.

questions.question: The wish in 3 John 1:2 that Gaius may prosper 'even as thy soul prospereth' reflects which Old Testament concept?
options: The holistic blessing of body and soul as in Jeremiah 29:11
The exclusive blessing of material wealth as in Job 1
The emphasis on ritual purity as in Leviticus 11
The promise of kingship as in 2 Samuel 7
questions.correctAnswer: The holistic blessing of body and soul as in Jeremiah 29:11
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:2 echoes Old Testament themes where wellbeing includes both physical health and spiritual prosperity, similar to Jeremiah 29:11's holistic blessing.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in 3 John 1:3-4 where the Elder expresses joy over the brethren's testimony and his children walking in truth?
options: Parallelism reinforcing the theme of walking in truth
Chiasm emphasizing a central message about love
Typology foreshadowing Christ's mission
Allegory about the church's struggle
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism reinforcing the theme of walking in truth
questions.explanation: The parallel structure in verses 3-4 highlights the Elder's joy in the faithful walk in truth, a key theme throughout the Johannine epistles.

questions.question: In 3 John 1:5-6, Gaius is commended for his 'charity.' The Greek word used here, 'philadelphia,' most closely means what?
options: Brotherly love or hospitality
Sacrificial love
Romantic love
Divine love
questions.correctAnswer: Brotherly love or hospitality
questions.explanation: The Greek term 'philadelphia' in 3 John 1:5-6 describes brotherly love, particularly hospitality toward fellow believers and strangers.

questions.question: According to 3 John 1:7, why did the brethren 'go forth' taking nothing from the Gentiles?
options: For the sake of the Lord's name
Because of financial constraints
In order to avoid Gentile customs
To emphasize Jewish exclusivity
questions.correctAnswer: For the sake of the Lord's name
questions.explanation: Verse 7 explains that the brethren traveled without accepting support from Gentiles to honor the name of Christ and avoid dependence on non-believers.

questions.question: 3 John 1:8 uses the term 'fellowhelpers to the truth.' What theological theme does this express?
options: Cooperation in advancing the Gospel mission
Separation from non-believers
Judgment against false teachers
The exclusive authority of the Elder
questions.correctAnswer: Cooperation in advancing the Gospel mission
questions.explanation: The phrase underscores the communal responsibility in supporting those who spread the truth of the Gospel, emphasizing partnership in ministry.

questions.question: What historical-cultural practice is reflected in 3 John 1:9-10 regarding Diotrephes' behavior towards the Elder and other brethren?
options: Church discipline and exclusion from community fellowship
Roman civic trials
Trade guild regulations
Synagogue leadership succession
questions.correctAnswer: Church discipline and exclusion from community fellowship
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 describe Diotrephes' refusal to welcome traveling brothers and his expulsion of those who wished to receive them, reflecting early church disciplinary measures.

questions.question: In 3 John 1:11, the Elder contrasts those who do good with those who do evil. How does this dualism relate to Johannine theology elsewhere?
options: It parallels the light versus darkness motif in John 1:5
It opposes the Law and Grace contrast in Romans
It reflects the prophetic condemnation in Isaiah
It corresponds to the wisdom literature's moral ambiguity
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels the light versus darkness motif in John 1:5
questions.explanation: The moral dualism in 3 John 1:11 aligns with the Johannine theme of light and darkness found in John 1:5, illustrating clear ethical distinctions.

questions.question: Why does the Elder commend Demetrius in 3 John 1:12, and what does this suggest about early Christian leadership?
options: He has a good report and is a trustworthy witness to the truth
He is wealthy and supports the church financially
He is a missionary to the Gentiles
He is a scribe who copied the Scriptures accurately
questions.correctAnswer: He has a good report and is a trustworthy witness to the truth
questions.explanation: Demetrius is praised for his reputation and faithfulness, indicating early Christian leaders were valued for character and testimony.

questions.question: What does the Elder mean in 3 John 1:13-14 when he says he will not write with ink and pen but hopes to speak face to face?
options: He prefers personal fellowship over written communication
He lacks writing materials
He doubts the reliability of letters
He is delaying communication due to persecution
questions.correctAnswer: He prefers personal fellowship over written communication
questions.explanation: The Elder expresses a desire for direct personal interaction, emphasizing the value of face-to-face fellowship over letters.

questions.question: True or False: According to 3 John 1:9-10, Diotrephes welcomed the Elder and the brethren warmly and supported their mission.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 state Diotrephes 'receiveth us not' and actively opposes the brethren, forbidding others from receiving them.

questions.question: The phrase 'for his name's sake' in 3 John 1:7 is an example of what biblical motif?
options: Suffering for the sake of God's honor
Legalistic adherence to the Law
Political allegiance to Rome
Personal ambition for honor
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering for the sake of God's honor
questions.explanation: This phrase reflects the motif of enduring hardship to uphold God's name, common in both Old and New Testament contexts.

questions.question: In 3 John 1:5, the Elder commends Gaius for his faithfulness. What ancient Near Eastern cultural value does this reflect?
options: Hospitality to guests and strangers
Military prowess
Temple ritual purity
Economic prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Hospitality to guests and strangers
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, hospitality was a key virtue, and Gaius' faithful service to brethren and strangers reflects this cultural and biblical value.

questions.question: How does the conflict with Diotrephes in 3 John 1:9-10 foreshadow later ecclesiastical struggles described in the New Testament?
options: It anticipates divisions and authority disputes as in 1 Timothy
It predicts the destruction of the temple in 70 AD
It references the Jewish-Roman wars
It describes the persecution under Nero
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates divisions and authority disputes as in 1 Timothy
questions.explanation: The challenge to apostolic authority by Diotrephes prefigures similar leadership conflicts addressed in pastoral epistles like 1 Timothy.

questions.question: The Elder's statement in 3 John 1:4 about having no greater joy than hearing his children walk in truth is an example of what kind of biblical relationship imagery?
options: Spiritual parenthood and discipleship
Patriarchal lineage
Covenantal kinship
Sacrificial shepherding
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual parenthood and discipleship
questions.explanation: The Elder uses familial language to express his pastoral role and joy in spiritual growth, a common motif in the New Testament.

theological.title: 3 John Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 3 John Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 3 John 1:2, what is the elder's primary desire for Gaius?
options: That he may prosper and be in health, even as his soul prospers
That he may travel safely and receive many gifts
That he may gain wealth and power among the brethren
That he may be a leader in the church
questions.correctAnswer: That he may prosper and be in health, even as his soul prospers
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:2 explicitly states the elder's wish for Gaius to prosper and be in health, just as his soul prospers. This reflects the biblical principle that physical well-being is connected to spiritual well-being, similar to Jeremiah 29:11, Psalm 1:3, Proverbs 3:7-8, and 1 Timothy 4:8.

questions.question: What does the elder claim brings him the greatest joy, according to 3 John 1:4?
options: Hearing that his children walk in truth
Receiving gifts from the brethren
Leading the church in public worship
Writing letters to the churches
questions.correctAnswer: Hearing that his children walk in truth
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:4 expresses the elder's supreme joy in hearing that his spiritual children walk in truth, emphasizing the importance of faithfulness and truth in Christian discipleship. This joy aligns with Paul's sentiments in Philippians 1:25-26, John 15:10, and Hebrews 13:21.

questions.question: In 3 John 1:9, who is identified as someone who 'loves to have the preeminence' and refuses to receive the elder and brethren?
options: Diotrephes
Demetrius
Gaius
The elder
questions.correctAnswer: Diotrephes
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:9 names Diotrephes as the individual who desires to have preeminence, refuses to welcome the elder and brethren, and opposes the truth. This exemplifies the biblical warning against pride and divisiveness, as seen in Proverbs 16:18, James 4:6, 1 Corinthians 3:3, and Titus 3:10.

questions.question: What is the elder's instruction regarding evil and good in 3 John 1:11?
options: Follow not that which is evil, but that which is good
Ignore evil as it is inevitable
Endure evil without complaint
Do good only when it benefits you
questions.correctAnswer: Follow not that which is evil, but that which is good
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:11 commands believers to reject evil and pursue good, stating that those who do good are of God while evil-doers have not seen God. This reflects the ethical imperative found in Romans 12:9, 1 Peter 3:11, Psalm 34:14, and Micah 6:8.

questions.question: How does 3 John 1:8 describe the proper response to those who have gone forth for the name of Christ?
options: We ought to receive such, that we might be fellowhelpers to the truth
We should test them thoroughly before accepting
We must require financial support from them
We should keep them at a distance to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: We ought to receive such, that we might be fellowhelpers to the truth
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:8 teaches that believers should welcome those who serve for Christ's name without seeking worldly gain, thereby partnering in advancing the truth. This aligns with principles in Matthew 10:40, Hebrews 13:2, Luke 10:16, and Acts 20:35.

questions.question: What testimony is borne about Demetrius in 3 John 1:12?
options: He has a good report of all men and of the truth itself
He is known for his eloquence and leadership
He is wealthy and generous to the church
He is a strict enforcer of church discipline
questions.correctAnswer: He has a good report of all men and of the truth itself
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:12 commends Demetrius for his good reputation among all and for his adherence to the truth, serving as a model of faithful Christian character. This is consistent with biblical commendations of good testimony in 1 Timothy 3:7, Titus 2:7, Proverbs 22:1, and Matthew 5:16.

questions.question: According to 3 John 1:7, why did the brethren go forth taking nothing from the Gentiles?
options: For His name's sake
Because they were poor
To avoid offending the Gentiles
As a test of their faith
questions.correctAnswer: For His name's sake
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:7 states that the brethren went forth without taking support from the Gentiles, motivated by their commitment to Christ's name rather than material gain, emphasizing selfless ministry as in Acts 20:33-35, 1 Corinthians 9:15-18, Philippians 2:5-8, and 2 Corinthians 11:7-9.

questions.question: What behavior of Diotrephes is described in 3 John 1:10?
options: He prates against the elder with malicious words, refuses to receive brethren, forbids those who want to receive them, and casts them out of the church
He humbly welcomes all brethren and supports the truth
He is silent and avoids confrontation
He encourages unity and peace among the brethren
questions.correctAnswer: He prates against the elder with malicious words, refuses to receive brethren, forbids those who want to receive them, and casts them out of the church
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:10 details Diotrephes’ malicious speech against the elder, his refusal to receive brethren, prohibition of others doing so, and expelling from the church, illustrating the dangers of pride and schism as warned in Romans 16:17, Titus 3:10, 2 Timothy 3:2, and Galatians 5:15.

questions.question: Who is the recipient of the elder's letter in 3 John 1:1?
options: Gaius
Demetrius
Diotrephes
John
questions.correctAnswer: Gaius
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:1 identifies Gaius as the beloved recipient of the elder's letter, whom he loves in truth, highlighting the personal and pastoral nature of the epistle. This personal address is similar to letters addressed to individuals in Romans 16:23, Philemon 1, and 2 Timothy 1:2.

questions.question: What does the elder say about the works of the beloved in 3 John 1:5?
options: He does faithfully whatsoever he does to the brethren and to strangers
He does only what benefits himself
He neglects the needs of strangers
He is inconsistent in his service
questions.correctAnswer: He does faithfully whatsoever he does to the brethren and to strangers
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:5 praises the beloved for faithful deeds toward both brethren and strangers, emphasizing hospitality and charity as marks of Christian love, consistent with Hebrews 13:2, Romans 12:13, Matthew 25:35-40, and Galatians 6:10.

questions.question: What is the elder's planned response to Diotrephes if he comes, according to 3 John 1:10?
options: He will remember his deeds
He will ignore him
He will commend him publicly
He will appoint him to leadership
questions.correctAnswer: He will remember his deeds
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:10 states that the elder will remember Diotrephes’ deeds when he comes, implying accountability and correction. This reflects biblical principles of church discipline and accountability found in Matthew 18:15-17, Galatians 6:1, 2 Corinthians 13:2, and 1 Timothy 5:20.

questions.question: How does the elder describe his intention to communicate further in 3 John 1:13?
options: He had many things to write but will not write with ink and pen
He plans to send a lengthy letter soon
He intends to stop all communication
He will communicate only through others
questions.correctAnswer: He had many things to write but will not write with ink and pen
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:13 reveals the elder’s intention not to write more letters, suggesting he prefers personal communication, reflecting the biblical value of face-to-face fellowship as in Acts 20:20, Romans 16:22, Philippians 2:19-24, and 1 Thessalonians 2:17-18.

questions.question: What does 3 John 1:6 indicate about the importance of providing for traveling brethren?
options: Bringing them forward after a godly sort is commendable
They should be left to fend for themselves
Only local brethren deserve support
Financial support is unnecessary for traveling brethren
questions.correctAnswer: Bringing them forward after a godly sort is commendable
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:6 highlights that supporting traveling brethren properly honors God and benefits the church, consistent with principles found in Luke 10:7, 1 Timothy 5:18, Acts 18:3, and Hebrews 13:16.

questions.question: What greeting and blessing does the elder offer at the conclusion of 3 John 1:14?
options: Peace be to thee. Our friends salute thee. Greet the friends by name.
Grace and mercy be multiplied to you
May the Lord bless your works abundantly
Rejoice always and be thankful
questions.correctAnswer: Peace be to thee. Our friends salute thee. Greet the friends by name.
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:14 closes the letter with a benediction of peace and greetings from friends, underscoring communal love and fellowship, paralleling greetings in Romans 16:16, 1 Corinthians 16:20, Philippians 4:21, and Colossians 4:18.

questions.question: What is the elder's assessment of the truth in Gaius as mentioned in 3 John 1:3?
options: The brethren testified of the truth in him as he walks in truth
He struggles to understand the truth
He preaches a different gospel
He is indifferent to the truth
questions.correctAnswer: The brethren testified of the truth in him as he walks in truth
questions.explanation: 3 John 1:3 recounts the elder's joy upon hearing the brethren testify that Gaius walks in truth, affirming genuine faithfulness in doctrine and practice. This is consistent with John 8:31-32, Ephesians 4:15, 2 Timothy 3:16-17, and 1 John 2:6.
